results.headline: Review: In ‘Closet Monster,’ a Teenager’s Self-Discovery Is Tinged With Danger
results.summary_short: An entrancing coming-of-age story about a young man at odds with his sexuality, and haunted by what he witnessed as a boy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Closet Monster

results.display_title: The Jazz Loft According to W. Eugene Smith
results.headline: Review: ‘The Jazz Loft According to W. Eugene Smith’
results.summary_short: When Smith, an esteemed photojournalist, moved to the flower district in Manhattan in the 1950s, he started shooting and taping his neighbors for almost a decade.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Jazz Loft According to W. Eugene Smith

results.headline: Review: In ‘Queen of Katwe,’ a Pawn Finds Her Crown Through Chess
results.summary_short: In this stirring underdog story directed by Mira Nair, Madina Nalwanga plays a young Ugandan with a gift for chess, supported by Lupita Nyong’o as her mother.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Queen of Katwe

results.headline: Review: ‘Audrie & Daisy,’ on Sexual Assault and Technology
results.summary_short: Audrey Pott committed suicide. Daisy Coleman spoke out against the legal system. This documentary tells their stories.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Audrie & Daisy

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Age of Shadows,’ Plot’s Fine, but Action’s Better
results.summary_short: Kim Jee-woon’s new action movie takes place in Korea in the 1920s, when the country was under Japanese occupation.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Age of Shadows

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Lovers and the Despot,’ a Harrowing Korean Ordeal
results.summary_short: This documentary looks at how and why a South Korean actress, Choi Eun-hee, and a once successful film director, Shin Sang-ok, landed in North Korea.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Lovers and the Despot

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Free World,’ Being Free Isn’t All It’s Cracked Up to Be
results.summary_short: Jason Lew’s directorial debut features a man wrongly imprisoned for a crime he didn’t commit who risks everything to help an abused wife.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Free World

results.headline: Review: In ‘Goat,’ Frat Brothers Unleash Their Sadistic Terror
results.summary_short: Nick Jonas and Ben Schnetzer star in this disturbing tale about the urge to belong, no matter what the cost.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Goat

results.headline: Review: In ‘I.T.,’ Smart House, Dumb Owner
results.summary_short: This thriller features a computer-controlled home owned by a businessman who isn’t very savvy when it comes to guarding his privacy from wrongdoers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I.T.

results.headline: Review: ‘My Blind Brother,’ Who Is Also a Major Pain
results.summary_short: Sibling rivalry arises between an arrogant blind athlete and his helpful underdog brother when they end up in a love triangle with an appealing young woman.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Blind Brother

results.headline: Review: ‘1000 Rupee Note,’ a Poor Widow’s Blessing and Curse
results.summary_short: In this film, set in the Maharashtra State of India, a villager sets off on a fraught shopping trip after receiving a few 1,000-rupee notes at a political rally.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 1000 Rupee Note

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Ruins of Lifta,’ a Dispute Amid the Rubble
results.summary_short: This documentary by Menachem Daum and Oren Rudavsky focuses on the fate of an old Arab village on the outskirts of Jerusalem.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Ruins of Lifta

results.headline: Review: In ‘Seed: The Untold Story,’ It’s Farmers Versus Big Business
results.summary_short: This documentary raises alarm about declining crop diversity, genetically altered seeds and the ownership of nature.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Seed: The Untold Story

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Dressmaker,’ a Femme Fatale Wants Vengeance
results.summary_short: Tilly Dunnage (Kate Winslet) returns to the dusty Australian hometown where she was bullied by a rich kid and blamed for his death.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Dressmaker

results.headline: Review: ‘Storks,’ an Uneasy Return to Delivering Babies
results.summary_short: A new animated film, aimed at young children, has an infant that needs a home and a bird on a mission.

results.headline: Review: Denzel Washington Rides High in ‘The Magnificent Seven’
results.summary_short: Ethan Hawke, Chris Pratt and Vincent D’Onofrio help round out the cast of this western remake, as outlaws who band together to protect a terrorized town.

results.headline: Review: A Rough Cut of ‘The Thief and the Cobbler’ Makes It to MoMA
results.summary_short: A dream project by the animator Richard Williams, this film, still in an incomplete state, screens through Tuesday at the Museum of Modern Art.

results.headline: Review: ‘Operation Avalanche,’ a Tale of Film Nerds on a Kubrick Caper
results.summary_short: Matt Johnson and Owen Williams star in this period comedy-thriller about film nerds on a spy mission sneaking onto a set of “2001: A Space Odyssey.”

results.headline: Review: In ‘Miss Stevens,’ a Chaperone Greets Temptation
results.summary_short: A young English teacher taking three students to an acting contest puts into question the student-adult relationship in this work from Julia Hart.

results.headline: Review: Bad Boy of the Royal Ballet Regains His Footing in ‘Dancer’
results.summary_short: Steven Cantor’s documentary profiles Sergei Polunin, the star of a Hozier video and a former principal who quit the troupe after only two years.
